Link Mash (May 1, 2014)

May 1, 2014
2 minute read

The weekly Link Mash is a curated selection of tools, stories, and other links that I found during my travels on the web. All of my links can be found on my Pinboard; you can also find the Link Mash archives here.

  • Project Naptha. You’re telling me I can copy/paste text in images in Chrome??
  • Ruby · Styleguide. A great reference for writing clean, clear Ruby.
  • Automating iOS: A Comprehensive Guide to Launch Center Pro. This the most amazing article I’ve seen in a long time. So many tips, tricks, and automations to make productivity easier.
  • Cakebrew. I’m a fan of Homebrew on the command line, but if you’re wanting a GUI, this is a great option.
  • Remotely Put Your Mac to Sleep from Your iPhone Using Drafts. Amazing what the combination of Drafts and Hazel can do!
  • Patton Oswalt’ s Star Wars Filibuster. A coworker reminded me of this today; one of the most amazing bits of ad-lib I’ve seen in my life.
  • The Star Wars Saga: Introducing Machete Order. IT MAKES SO MUCH SENSE. My wife is an initiate and I think we’re going to try out this theory with her…
  • Marvel Comics Developer API. What a fantastic idea. This is what the next several weeks will look like.
  • Instantly Find Space Hogs on Your Mac with a Spotlight Trick. Clever trick if you aren’t aware where your bandwidth hogs are.
  • On the Past, Present and Future of Apple’s Aqua User Interface. A great look at how Apple has slowly progressed the Aqua interface.
  • iOS Security. A little dense, but a great primer on how Apple’s iOS security model works.
  • 10.8: AppleScript to close iCal Alerts. HALLELUJAH. I’ve needed this for ages – finally, a way to close a bunch of notifications on OSX at once!
  • Improve Your Resume with This Simple Formula Recommended by Google. Not sure if this works as scientifically as Google thinks, but it’s interesting to consider.
  • Use the Mayfair and Inkwell Filters to Get More Reactions on Instagram. Aha! I’m going to get right on it.
  • Atom: a hackable text editor for the 21st Century. Despite all the bad allegations coming out of Github these days, Atom is a bright spot. Might eventually replace Textmate 2 for me.
  • Technical Debt, a case study : tags. A look at how programmers solve complex problems iteratively.

This Link Mash was generated by PinPress, a simple tool to generate text templates from Pinboard data.
